header_summary:
The WizardSardine development team has made significant strides in implementing an encryption scheme for Liana wallet descriptors, inspired by Salvatore Ingala's publication, leading to the creation of draft implementations and a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) for community review. The resources include a draft BIP, a Rust implementation with a CLI, and a GUI leveraging the Rust implementation, with the community invited to provide feedback on cryptographic choices, including nonce generation, cipher selection, and encoding strategies ([GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1951), [Rust CLI GitHub](https://github.com/pythcoiner/encrypted_backup), [GUI GitHub](https://github.com/pythcoiner/bed), [DelvingBitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/a-simple-backup-scheme-for-wallet-accounts)).

Christopher Allen highlights the integration of FROST with Bitcoin technology, enhancing security through Distributed Key Generation (DKG) and showcasing its application in signing Partially Signed Bitcoin Transactions (PSBTs) with Taproot adjustments. The project, supported by various organizations and community members, aims to advance understanding and application of FROST through demonstrations, resources, and developer meetings, fostering Bitcoin's security and functionality enhancements ([video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8csdApREJIs), [code walkthrough](https://hackmd.io/y6EYPYR0SluE0M0az7Y3uw), [FROST events](https://developer.blockchaincommons.com/frost/events)).

Fjahr's discussion on network-level attacks on Bitcoin, particularly focusing on BIP324 and StratumV2's mitigation potential, suggests exploring alternative connection types and improving attack methodology clarity. The correspondence advocates for strategic peer rotation and enhanced node operator awareness to bolster Bitcoin's network resilience, emphasizing the need for collaboration and knowledge dissemination on security practices ([DelvingBitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/eclipsing-bitcoin-nodes-with-bgp-interception-attacks/1965/6)).

The exploration into the Simplicity blockchain programming language by roconnor-blockstream reveals its potential for creating complex computations and cryptographic functions within a minimalistic design framework. With developments in handling data types, arithmetic operations, and cryptographic implementations, Simplicity demonstrates flexibility and depth, indicating its capability to support secure and efficient blockchain applications and smart contracts ([DelvingBitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/delving-simplicity-part-building-data-types/1956)).

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Add BIP-0093 (Codex32) as application to BIP-0085
active_posts.summary:
- Ben Westgate proposes integrating BIP-0093 with BIP-0085 for deterministic wallet backups.
- Codex32, under BIP-93, aims for enhanced BIP-0032 seed backups via human-readable formats and secret sharing.
- The proposal seeks to standardize codex32 backup generation and has begun gaining momentum in Bitcoin Core discussions.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] OP_TWEAKADD
active_posts.summary:
- Jeremy shared a draft BIP proposing a new Bitcoin opcode, OP_TWEAKADD.
- OP_TWEAKADD aims to enhance scripting with push semantics and ease of use.
- Feedback is sought from the Bitcoin community for potential refinement.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Elliptic Curve Operations for Bitcoin Script
active_posts.summary:
- A proposal aims to enhance Bitcoin scripting with Elliptic Curve operation op codes.
- These op codes enable dynamic smart contract creation on Bitcoin's blockchain.
- The effort introduces advanced scripting potential, inviting contributions and technical discussion.

active_posts.title: Who will run the CoinJoin coordinators?
active_posts.summary:
- The crackdown on privacy tools affects Bitcoin privacy services, leading to key closures.
- New alternatives like JoinMarket and the BTCPay Server CoinJoin plugin are emerging.
- The author has launched their own BTCPay coordinator to support transactional privacy.

active_posts.title: CVE-2024-38365 public disclosure (btcd `FindAndDelete` bug)
active_posts.summary:
- Niklas Gögge and Antoine Poinsot found a significant flaw in Btcd versions before 0.24.2.
- Their discovery revealed a deviation in signature verification rules that could enable node forking.
- The issue was resolved with a covert fix in version 0.24.2 after a diligent, coordinated effort.

today_in_history_posts.title: New transaction policies (nVersion=3) for contracting protocols
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin developers aim to enhance v3 transactions, emphasizing limiting OP_TRUE outputs.
- Gloria Zhao suggests mempool policies to support Layer 2/contract protocols, focusing on preventing pinning attacks.
- Proposed RBF policy changes will alter transaction replacement and mining incentives.

today_in_history_posts.title: Fee Ratecards (your gateway to negativity)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The Lightning Network introduces ratecards for flexible channel capacity pricing with negative fee options.
- Ratecards update automatically, reducing bandwidth and allowing precise liquidity pricing.
- A linked presentation at a Bitcoin meetup covers cryptocurrency trends, privacy, and decentralization challenges.

today_in_history_posts.title: Hardcoded seeds, DNS seeds and Darknet nodes
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Hardcoded seed data's role in darknet node connectivity to Bitcoin without DNS seeds highlights varying viability across network types.
- The failure to update seed nodes in Bitcoin Core version 26 emphasizes the need for current seed lists for network robustness.
- A new proof-of-concept darknet seeder aims to enhance connectivity by serving Onion, I2P, and Cjdns addresses with BIP155-like encoding.
